content: TDD cycle: RED (failing test) → GREEN (minimal pass) → REFACTOR (clean up). No exceptions. Tests are specification, not afterthought.
Commit after each completed task, not just at story end. Enables recovery, shows progress, creates clean history for debugging.
Full skill cycle even for small stories — the overhead is minimal and structure helps. Design → Plan → Implement → Review → Close.
Ask before spawning subagents (inference economy). Gather with tools, think with inference. AI computation is a resource to steward.
HITL (Human In The Loop) is default. Pause after significant work for review. Slow is smooth, smooth is fast.
Design-first eliminates ambiguity. Concrete examples in specs enable direct implementation without guessing intent.
Epic branch must exist before /rai-epic-design (poka-yoke). Story branches nest under epic branches. This enforces merge flow.
Story branch and scope commit required before implementation. /rai-story-start creates traceability from first commit.
Retrospective required before story/epic close. Extract learnings, update patterns. Kaizen, one story at a time.
Epic close with retrospective before merge to development branch. Captures learning at meso-layer between stories and quarters.
Direct communication, no praise-padding. 'Great question!' adds no value. Say what needs saying, then stop.
Redirect when dispersing (with permission). Tangents go to parking lot. Return to stated goal.
Epistemological rigor: triangulate claims (2+ sources), explicit confidence levels, acknowledge contrary evidence. Stand on shoulders of giants.
Honesty over agreement. Push back on bad ideas. Admit uncertainty rather than pretend confidence. Your judgment is the quality gate.
Type annotations on all code. Function parameters, return types, class attributes. Pyright strict mode is the standard.
Pydantic models for all data structures. Not dict, not TypedDict. Validation at boundaries, serialization for free.
Simple heuristics over complex ML. Keyword matching is 98% accurate. Token estimate = words × 1.3. Complexity must earn its place.
Tests alongside implementation, not after. Write the test, watch it fail, make it pass. Catches issues immediately.
Skills + Toolkit over Engines. Users need flexibility (skills as process guides) + determinism (CLI for data operations).
Jidoka: stop on defects. When incoherence, ambiguity, or drift detected — stop, name it, discuss. Don't accumulate errors.
Supabase Edge Functions import npm packages via esm.sh CDN: https://esm.sh/@supabase/supabase-js@2
OpenAI Vision responses may wrap JSON in markdown code blocks — extract with regex /{[\s\S]*}/ before JSON.parse
For single-file stories, combine tightly coupled tasks into one commit rather than tracking separately — decomposition is useful for thinking but overhead for execution
Full story lifecycle (start → design → plan → implement → review → close) can complete in a single session for moderate Edge Function stories

Validation stories: use structured audit table (PASS/FAIL/PARTIAL per checklist item with file:line evidence). Design phase can be skipped (Simple complexity) when the checklist itself serves as the spec.
Confirm intent when a skill is re-invoked after being explicitly skipped — user may have meant a different command
Retroactive epic homologation: create scope.md from existing specs, update backlog, rebuild memory. Three steps to bring pre-framework work into RaiSE traceability.

Archive-with-traceability: Move legacy files to archive location with SUPERSEDED banners linking to current governance. Components: prominent warning, context (why archived), link to current, original content preserved. Reusable for any legacy doc migration.

Index-with-bridge: Create navigation index in new structure (RaiSE) that links to legacy artifacts in historical location. Components: clear context (why bridge exists), comprehensive artifact listing, working relative links, _origin marker for provenance. Reusable for any framework migration.

Nomenclature migration: When project naming evolves, create bidirectional mapping table (legacy → canonical), add canonical declaration to governance (prominent location), provide future guidance (use canonical, legacy is historical only), mark unmapped items clearly. Preserves traceability without rewriting historical docs.

Homologation pre-check: Before creating artifacts in homologation/migration tasks, verify target directory for existing content. Use ls or find before Write/Create to detect conflicts. Prevents duplicates in doc migration work.

ADR structure: Decision (what we're doing), Rationale (why, with Alternatives Considered subsection), Context (situation + references to commits/files), Consequences (positive + negative + mitigation), References (related work). Comprehensive ADRs: 140-220 lines. Traceability via commit hashes.
